resource.chars:
Mr Raineys paper consists of three parts; the 
first containing observations on the seat 
and structure of the fully-formed Cysticercus 
cellulosae - the second an account of the 
phenomena, conceived by the author to 
accompany its origin & development, and the 
third some considerations “entirely of a 
theoretical nature”.
The first part appears to contain nothing 
which has not been often more fully &
quite as accurately described & figured elsewhere.
One point upon which Mr Rainey appears to 
lay some stress, viz: that the striped muscles 
are peculiarly if not solely the seat of origin 
of the Cysticercus, is so opposed to all observation 
on the matter, that it would be unnecessary to 
advert to it
